"We need to raise the minimum wage, strengthen labor, rewrite our trade agreements, make college affordable, invest in our infrastructure, education, research, energy and jobs."

In other words, we need to reverse 35 years of the Reagan Revolution and take America back to where she was in the 60's and 70's when we had a strong middle class and growing prosperity.

Too many young people don't know that America had all of those things once upon a time.

To address this insanity, Sen. Sanders will be introducing legislation to break up the big banks.

Bernie Sanders: It has become abundantly clear that Congress does not regulate Wall Street but Wall Street regulates Congress. If Wall Street lobbyists can literally write a provision into law that will allow too-big-to-fail banks to make the same risky bets that nearly destroyed our economy just a few years ago, it should be obvious to all that their incredible economic and political power is a huge danger to our economy and our way of life.

Almost 60 percent of discretionary spending goes to the military and perpetual war. There are cuts to the EPA at a time when we need to address climate change in a bold way. There are cuts to the IRS which means it will have less manpower to go after tax cheats. The are cuts to pensions which means that people who have worked their entire lives will see cuts of 30, 40, 50 percent.

The priorities in this budget are wrong. The median wage was only $28,031 last year. We need to raise the minimum wage, to a living wage, strengthen labor legislation, and rewrite our disastrous trade agreements. We need to make college affordable again. We need to make significant investments in our crumbling infrastructure, education, research, energy efficiency and clean energy, which would create millions of good jobs.

David has a point, but he can't lump all derivatives together.  They vary greatly in (a) utility, (b) speculative character, (c) risk, and (d) whom they attract.  The (true) hedges used by businesses to stabilize their costs of materials are derivatives, but they have little else in common with credit default swaps, collateralized debt obligations, and other "higher" (in the technical sense) forms of derivative.

Addicts don't care about moral hazard. They don't care who provides them with their next hit. What they need is the next fix. One irony is that an addiction to power is a weakness. So the the instinct of the junkie is to take their fix on the sly, dark allies or away from prying eyes, to insure the hits keep coming. The biggest obstacle to keeping them from coming in is if the sources of those hits become transparent and well known.

So the Wall Street Junkies paid both sides, one to deliver the hit, and the other to keep quiet about it. It was hush money. The system then is rigged in Wall Street's favor, the average Joe senses this, but their is no articulation from Pols or media as to why, so the system remains unabated and the hits and fixes keep flowing to the Junkies on Wall Street.

The large pool of claims on the underlying assets are mostly calls, puts and similar exotic derivatives that cancel each other out. The inflated value of all claims are mostly on tiered short and long-term financial securities including currencies, bonds and similar debt instruments which reflects the size of global debt that funds government and global enterprises. The futures markets are distorted in value by these huge pools of currency derivatives and government and sovereign debt instruments.

The Financial Crisis was based on a different kettle of rotting fish. The under-performing sub-prime mortgages were buried within a package of debt securities sold to dealers as high-grade securities. The truth was much different. The underlying assets - the mortgage securities bundles - were much less value than sold and the series of options and exotic derivatives written for and against those securities were exponentially larger than the true value of the underlying mortgages. When the truth hit the fan it spread like a virus and banking centers with weaker back-stops were killed - Iceland, Greece, and those others survived with the help of drafted Taxpayers.

Well, in addition to DGA's correct observation that Wall Street is has been a much bigger backer of this President than his Republican rivals, it is also not quite correct that financial professionals have no history of policing themselves, with the most important example being that of accountants (and to some extent with the actuarial community). Although Congress and then the SEC have ultimate authority over accounting standards, they have largely delegated authority to the industry bodies known as FASB (Financial Accounting Standards Board) and GASB (Government Accounting Standards Board). These bodies have existed for so long that most people forget that they are perhaps the best examples of a financial industry working well to police itself and create standards that are adhered to in order to create a healthier industry for everyone. Of course, if absolutely needed, the SEC and Congress can swoop in but in practice, that is not necessary, although the threat of potential intervention is likely healthy.

Why this is relevant is that there is some ability and incentive for other financial professionals and companies to create and maintain a healthy environment in their financial institutions for the benefit of all concerned. This should be encouraged with the example set by the accountants in their running of FASB and GASB entitites. Fianncial professionals need to be drawn in as part of the solution or they will remain central to the problem.
